vote.title: Arts Justice: Access and Equity Across the Disciplines and the District
vote.description: Whereas, On June 22, 2021 the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District adopted four Board Goals committing the Los Angeles Unified School District to improve student achievement in post-secondary preparation, literacy, numeracy, and social-emotional wellness; Whereas, Participating in arts education promotes creativity, wellness, healing and socio-emotional learning, which are foundational skills to achieving the Board goals; Whereas, California Education Code sections 51210 and 51220 provide that California schools must provide a course of study for students in grades 1 through 12 with courses or instruction in visual and performing arts, including dance, music, theater, and visual arts, aimed at the development of aesthetic appreciation and the skills of creative expression; Whereas, The State of California recognizes the arts as an integral part of a quality education by requiring the completion of a visual and performing arts (VAPA) course for students wishing to pursue higher education in California’s four-year public colleges; Whereas, Education Code 49011 requires that no pupil enrolled in a public school shall be required to pay to participate in an educational activity and students have the right to access all educational materials for extracurriculars or classes including but not limited to instruments, arts supplies or dance/cheer uniforms; Whereas, The California Arts Content Standards for Public Schools, Prekindergarten through Grade 12: Dance, Media Arts, Music, Theatre, Visual Arts, was adopted by the State Board of Education on January 9, 2019, to foster students’ artistic competencies; cultivate their appreciation and understanding of the arts in ways that are enjoyable, fulfilling, and transferable to personal, academic, and professional endeavors; and support them to fully engage in lifelong arts learning;Whereas, The California Arts Education Framework for Public Schools, Transitional Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve (Arts Framework) was adopted by the State Board of Education on July 8, 2020 to provide guidance for educational programs on how to implement standards based arts education. Whereas, Since 1980 the Board has adopted over 10 Board Resolutions committed to strengthening arts access and programming at the local and state levels, including in a 2012 resolution entitled, “Supporting Educational Equity, Student Achievement and Mastery of 21st Century Skills through Arts at the Core” affirming the arts as a part of core academic instruction, including direct and integrated instruction; Whereas, In 2013, the Board passed a resolution entitled, “Arts at the Core: Implementing the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan,” which called on the Superintendent to develop a plan to distribute and support the use of state and federal guidelines to administrators and school site stakeholders, integrate comprehensive arts education and arts teaching and learning, collect and disseminate data to ensure accurate and transparent information regarding equitable access to arts education, and develop budget ideas to significantly increase funding for arts education; Whereas, In 2015, the Arts Education Branch created the Arts Equity Index to assess arts programming across all schools and to help inform how K-12 arts personnel and resources are administered; Whereas, The County of Los Angeles Board of Supervisors adopted the new Los Angeles County Regional Blueprint for Arts Education on October 13, 2020, which sets forth a vision, policy, and guide for increasing equity and access in arts education for all young people across Los Angeles County, prioritizing those who have been historically excluded from learning in the arts, both in schools and in communities; Whereas, Research documents the benefits of an arts education including developed critical thinking, problem-solving, imagination, creativity, alternative ways to communicate ideas, self-esteem, empathy, academic and personal success, and students from low-income backgrounds with high access to arts in school are more likely to graduate, more likely to finish college, and register to vote than students without access to arts; Whereas, The COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted our school communities and students’ mental health and the arts have the potential to heal trauma and decrease stress and anxiety; Whereas, An equitable Path to Recovery requires providing additional resources to our high and highest need schools including ensuring that students have access to comprehensive and rigorous coursework including arts education, now, therefore be itResolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District, as part of a comprehensive approach to achieve the Board Goals, to achieve the goals of the California State Arts Content Standards, and to meet the requirements set forth in California Education Codes 51210 and 51220, commits to equitable access to high quality, standards-based, comprehensive, sequential,culturally relevant and developmentally appropriate arts education across disciplines to all PK-12 students regardless of race, ethnicity, country of origin, family income, neighborhood of residence, gender, gender identity, disability, sexual orientation, and any other axis of historical oppression; Resolved further, That the Superintendent will analyze and respond to gaps in access to arts programming, reporting back to the Board and public within 120 days and annually with information such as: 1. What percentage of students meaningfully participate in each of the five arts disciplines (visual arts, music, dance, theater, and media arts), at least once during the instructional day disaggregated by grade level (including early education, elementary, middle and high school), and by race/ethnicity, disability, and/or language? 2. What percentage of students are in which types of programs (e.g. elective course, 9-week program, semester-long, year-long, after school extracurricular program, magnet school, in-school partnership with an external organization, or no program)? 3. How are these arts disciplines and programs funded and made available to schools (e.g. central allocation, Community of Schools (COSA) funded, school site funded, parent organization or booster club funded, community organization donation, and funding from the Arts Equity Index)? 4. How is the Arts Equity Index currently used to guide equitable investments in Arts Education? (e.g. which schools get additional funding, how much funding is allocated through the index annually etc.) 5. What are the gaps in arts education enrollment, including student-teacher ratios and arts partnerships, across SENI quintiles, Local District, Community of School, Board District, race/ethnicity, disability and/or language? How and when will these gaps be closed? 6. How equitable is access to arts facilities and equipment across schools and programs (e.g. design, renovation, construction)? What do programs have and/or need to achieve equity? 7. Potential additions or revisions to the school experience survey or other open data-collection sources to regularly review and respond to access and equity in arts education; and, be it finally Resolved, That the Los Angeles Unified School District will intentionally build and strengthen the quality and quantity of arts education, through collaborative efforts that may include: 1.	Planning to fill the gaps in current arts programming so that every student PK- 12 has an equitable opportunity to access and experience robust, comprehensive, and sequential standards-based arts instruction and courses in each of the arts disciplines during the instructional day at every grade level by ensuring a baseline of core instructional services of arts education;2.	Creating Community of Schools arts pathways to create a sequential and cohesive arts curriculum across grade levels; 3. 	Providing additional arts opportunities through supplemental school-site partnerships with arts education organizations and institutions, making publicly available a database of partners (including what services they provide, in which arts discipline(s) and which schools they partner with); 4.	Ensuring a PK-12 curriculum and pedagogy that is culturally responsive, trauma- and resiliency- informed, and inclusive for all students across identities, skills, disabilities and learning differences; and 5. 	Establishing an arts advisory council, composed of at least seven students enrolled in 6-12th grades across all Board Districts, credentialed educators across all five arts disciplines and grade spans, and relevant arts-focused partners, to analyze data gathered, inform decision making, and provide an annual update to the Board on Arts Justice progress based on qualitative and quantitative student data.
